# Conceptual framework

## Nonstationary extreme value models

Generic nonstationary model for annual maximum precipitation:
$$
y(\vb{s}, t) \sim \text{GEV} (\mu(\vb{s}, t), \sigma(\vb{s}, t), \xi(\vb{s}, t))
$$

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
**Process-informed** models condition parameters on climate indices $\vb{X}(t)$ and spatial feature $\vb{Z}(\vb{s})$ [@schlef_idf:2023;@cheng_nonstationary:2014;@salas_review:2018]
$$
\theta(\vb{s}, t) = \alpha + \beta(\vb{s}) \times \vb{X}(t) + \phi \times \vb{Z}(\vb{s})
$$
where $\theta \in \{\mu, \sigma, \xi \}$
:::

# Case study

## Data

::: {#fig-nobs}
![](../_assets/img/lu-2023/2023-11-09/raw_data_nobs_199s.png){width=100%}

We retain 199 GHCND stations which have at least 30 years with 362+ days of data.
Colors indicate number of years of data used.
:::

## Spatially Varying Covariates

::: {.fragment}
Bayesian hierarchical space-time model:
$$
\begin{aligned}
y(\vb{s}, t) &\sim \text{GEV} (\mu(\vb{s}, t), \sigma(\vb{s}, t), \xi) \\
\mu(\vb{s}, t) &= \alpha^\mu + \beta^\mu_1(\vb{s}) \times \ln \text{CO}_2(t) \\
\log \sigma(\vb{s}, t) &= \alpha^\sigma + \beta^\sigma_1(\vb{s}) \times \ln \text{CO}_2(t) \\ 
\end{aligned}
$$
:::

::: {.fragment}
Assume: **latent** parameters $\alpha^\mu, \beta^\mu_1, \alpha^\sigma, \beta^\sigma_1$ are smooth in space.
Hierarchical spatial prior:
$$
\theta(\vb{s}) \sim \text{GP} \left( m, K(\vb{s}, \vb{s}') \right)
$$
for $\theta \in \{\alpha^\mu, \beta^\mu_1, \alpha^\sigma, \beta^\sigma_1 \}$ and
$K = \alpha^2 \exp \left(-\frac{ \| \vb{s} - \vb{s}' \| }{\rho} \right)$ 
:::

## Shifting and widening of the distribution {.smaller}

::: {#fig-trend-coeffs}
![](../_assets/img/lu-2023/2023-11-09/map_parameters_point_199s.png)

Posterior mean of trend coefficients.
Specifically, how much do
(T): location parameter and
(B): log scale parameter
increase with $\ln \text{CO}_2$?
For reference, an increase from 300 (pre-industrial) to 400 (current) ppm is approximately 0.29 on the log scale and an increase from 400 to 500 (mid-century under RCP 4.5/6) is approximately 0.22.
:::

## Discussion

::: {.incremental}
1. Brand new results -- validation ongoing and feedback appreciated
1. Is Atlas 14 too high in SE TX [@nielsen-gammon_harris:2020]?
    - Small "region of influence" neglects that Harvey could have hit a wide range
    - Stationary model, short-record stations, sampling only from recent years (Missing at Random)
1. Are our results too low in SE TX?
    - Possible over-smoothing ($\rho$ large)
    - Daily maxima $\neq$ 24 hour maxima
    - Separate trends for $\mu$ and $\sigma$
:::

## Parametric duration dependence (ongoing) {.smaller}

Adding a few parameters, we explicitly and flexibly model the GEV parameters as a function of duration $d$ [@ulrich_idf:2020; @koutsoyiannis_idf:1998; @fauer_idf:2021]:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma (d) &=  \sigma_0 (d + \theta) ^ {\eta_1 + \eta_2 }  + \tau \\
\mu (d) &= \tilde{\mu} (\sigma_0 (d + \theta ) ^ {-\eta_1 }  + \tau)
\end{aligned}
$$

::: {#fig-fauer}
![](../_assets/img/external-papers/fauer-idf-2021-2.png)

Duration-dependent parameterizations can capture multiple IDF curve behaviors [@fauer_idf:2021]
:::

# Conclusions

## Summary

Spatially Varying Covariates Model

::: {.incremental}
1. Bayesian space-time model with latent parameters (including trends) assumed to be smooth in space
1. Flexible approach yields credible inferences
1. Probabilistic framework to integrate future improvements
:::
